zone.line: ceiving it to be the only p ambition
worthy for him to aim at in the world.
By a strange narrowness of ideas
he viewed all the world in connexion only,
as it was or was not related to his little
society. He considered queer and out of
fashion all opinions that were
exploded ^by in his circle of fr intimates,
and he became at the same time
dogmatic and yet fearful of not coin
ciding with the only feelings^sentiments he could
consider orthodox. To the generality of
spectatior spectators he appeared careless
of censure, and with high disdain
to throw aside all dependance ^on to public
prejudices; but at the same time that
he strode with a triumphant stride
over the rest of the world, he cowered,
with self disguised lowliness, to his own
party, and although its chief, he never
dared express an opionion or a feeling
untill he was assured that it would
